Your genuine enthusiasm is fantastic and having been to the Masters on three occasions (1985, 1988 and 1992), I can echo everything you have said about its perfection and quality. The course is a complete oasis within the town. Its nature and fauna is outstanding, as are the Patrons. I recall one older one who sat all day and all alone on the right hand side of the 5th at about 350 yards off the tee. He had a sun hat with 25 Masters passes clipped onto it - a perfect spectator. I am sure your own memories will remain with you for a very long time and in particular those of actually playing the course. Thankyou for all the enjoyment that you and your colleagues bring to all your subscribers.

Very jealous but glad you got to have such an amazing experience, well deserved.
Wow what a great experience this must have been.  And I am so glad that you hit a great tee shot on #1.  Quite a few years ago I took a trip to Ireland hoping to play at Lahinch.  If you are not familiar with it it was laid out by Old Tom Morris and it is often referred to as the St. Andrews of Ireland.  Anyway I got there late in the day only to find out that they were closing it the next day for renovations.  But they told me I could go out right then even though it was late in the afternoon.  So I grabbed my clubs and headed for the first tee when I notice there were quite a few locals standing on the porch of the clubhouse watching me.  These guys looked like they stepped right out of "The Quiet Man".  They all had fishermans sweaters and those flat caps and several of them were smoking meerschaum pipes!  And I could tell that they were wondering if this American tourist could play so I was pretty nervous because frankly, I love to play but the most charitable thing you can say about my golf game is that I am a "high handicapper."  So I looked up to heaven and prayed to Bobby Jones.  "Bob, I'm in a tough spot here and I really need to hit a good tee shot.  If you could pull a few strings and help me out here I'd really appreciate it!"  Then I took my stance drew my club back and walloped a shot right down the middle and over the hill!  As I headed for my ball I heard a polite subdued round of applause from the gallery.  One of my happiest memories.
Once in a lifetime so happy for you guys!

I know it's nothing like playing Augusta, but I played Oakmont CC 2 days after the US Open in 1983.  I have played it 4 other times, but when we played that week the rough wasn't cut and the greens were ridiculous.  We played from the regular member tees. Glad you were able to play .. wish you could have videoed but understand policy.
I was a "COVID cancel victim" is 2020, skipped over for 2021, rained out in 2022 and FINALLY got to walk the grounds in 2023. The elevation changes are much bigger than you can see on TV. You can only guess how difficult the greens are by watching the players practice. Example: the favored area to miss is right of the green on #11. From there, in two hours of watching, I think we saw 2 shots stop within 6 feet of the front-left pin placement. The closest shots came from the approach shots. Just really difficult to get up-and-down. Glad you got the experience, Rick.
so cool!  I can't imagine how hard putting is - must be like shooting on ice!

Rick, I was fortunate enough to be at Augusta National on Wednesday, Thursday, and Sunday this year.  It was my second trip (last was 2015).  There were many highlights for which could be discussed.  The 2-3 hours spent at Amen corner Sunday drinking adult beverages, enjoying the golf of Sam Bennett finish at 4 under Thursday, or just walking around holes 12-14 after the final groups passed and crowds left and virtually no one was there.  Just being at Augusta National is so surreal.  What brought it back was Thursday on the #1 green. DeChambeau missed the green and was chipping 3rd shot, and he hits it fat!  Not too bad but enough where he was still chipping the 4th shot.  I was maybe 3 feet away on the ropes and you could see him calculating and visualizing his shot, and he "duffs" it.  I felt bad for him but it made golf so real that even the Pros make the same mistakes we do.
No one deserves it more than this man!
Fantastic news. I would love to visit here one day. ğŸ˜Š

Congratulations on playing the Augusta National course!! I was fortunate to attend the 2017 Sunday final (Sergio's win) and for 2018 I drew 4 Monday practice round  (Tiger's return) tickets for myself, my best friend, his son and my son-in-law, we had an EPIC time. TV cameras  don't do justice to how undulating the course layout is (hole #10 alone has to drop 60-70 ft down which you don't really see on TV!). The amazing thing about the course is that it's smack dab in the middle of town behind hedges!! I worked with a saleman who had customers in Georgia and he said that a lot of members go there to play cards the rest of the year since most members live across the country. The hospitality of the town was full of southern charm.
Unmatched! Congrats on the continued success!

I feel ya that not many things feel better than hitting a perfect drive.   I just wanted to say that I probably hit one of best drives of my life on the first hole at Pebble Beach back in 2015. Unfortunately I had to give up the game entirely at the age of 37 due to an injury. It sucks but it is what it is I guess. I had gotten down to as low as a 1.2 USGA handicap, but typically played to a a  2.0.     I was playing with my dad and brother and we were watching people tee off for like 30 minutes or maybe even a little more before we  teed off. Everybody was either playing from either the regular tees or the senior tees.  My brother went up to the the regular tees, my dad went to the senior tees and I went to the tips. The starter came back to me to me and said â€œAre you sure you want to play from back here? This is is a pretty hard course.â€ I said â€œYeah Iâ€™m good.â€ He asked me what my handicap was and I said â€œIâ€™m a 2.â€ He said â€œAlright.â€  I canâ€™t really blame the guy. Iâ€™m sure heâ€™s seen a million so called single digit handicap players that want to play the tips at Pebble Beach duff their opening tee shot. It is actually an intimidating atmosphere since there are a lot of people watching.   Anyway, I took my 3 wood out and aimed right at the bunker on the left side of the dogleg and just hit a bullet with a little cut. It was one of the purest shots Iâ€™ve ever hit. I just picked up my tee, glanced at the starter, handed my club to my caddie and started to walk down the fairway.

Wow you are the envy of all the weekend hackers.  Check out the golf course called Geneva National.   It is in Lake Geneva, WI.  This golf course has 3 courses.  The courses were designed by Palmer, Trevino & Player.  I love the Player's course and the 13 hole is the signature hole.  It is an elevated par 3 with tall thistles in front of the tee box.
